text: The drunkard’s steps drew closer, the cups on the table trembling slightly with each heavy footfall. The air grew thick with the stench of alcohol.
I didn’t back away. Slowly, I placed my hand on the hilt of my short sword, fingers tightening just enough to feel its weight.
The drunkard hesitated for a moment, his mouth twitching as if amused. He clearly didn’t take me seriously and took another step forward.
A flash of steel—my sword was already drawn. The blade’s chill traced a thin white line across his throat.
He froze completely, breath caught in his chest, not daring to even move his eyes.
“Move again, and I’ll call the town guards.”
The drunkard swallowed hard, his throat trembling lightly against the blade.
I didn’t answer. The blade pressed just an inch closer, the cold gleam reflected on his face, freezing even the sweat on his skin.
Only the crackle of the fire and his ragged breathing filled the silence.
Alicia stood nearby, watching calmly. A faint glimmer of approval flickered in her eyes.
The drunkard staggered backward, nearly tripping over himself as he bolted for the door, crashing into the storm outside.
With a loud bang, the door slammed shut in the wind, and the fire flickered softly.
I lowered my short sword. Its blade caught the firelight, glinting faintly like a streak of frozen lightning.
“You really have a talent for intimidation.”
“Someone had to do something,” I said with a wry smile, sliding the sword back into its sheath.
